review: A patchwork quilt of wish fulfillment and dream for all the single ladies out there, the senior single ladies. Blythe Danner is our ever elegant surrogate in this day trip to Autumn, a wineglass never far from her graceful fingers, and capably aided by friends Mary Kay Place and Rhea Perlman. The highlight: Danner's version of the delectable "Cry Me A River". Like many of the dreams of filmdom though no hair is ever out of place, and even an intrusive rodent seems tame and Disney- fied.

Beautiful from start to finish, "I'll See You in My Dreams" follows Carol, a middle-aged woman who recently lost her dog, and is still getting over her late husband of 20 years. Following her as she learns to let go of certain aspects of here life and welcome in new people is just an amazing viewing experience. Blythe Danner and Sam Elliott share fantastic chemistry, as does Martin Starr. Essentially, this picture is about learning to let go, let in, and learn about life in general. There are so many hidden messages about life throughout this film, that it will demand multiple viewings. With extremely believable dialogue, superb direction, and brilliant performances, "I'll See You in My Dreams" may be in the tight race for my favourite film of 2015. This is as simple of a premise as you can get, but the maturity level of screenplay is cranked up to eleven, which makes it that much more engaging. To me, this little film is a revelation, I (to put it bluntly), cannot find a single thing to complain about. "I'll See You in My Dreams" is beautiful.

I absolutely loved I'll See You in My Dreams, which opened the Cleveland International Film Fest in 2015!! It succeeds because of the funny, sweet and stellar ensemble cast. Carol Petersen (Blythe Danner) is a widow with a routine. She lives independently, but visits her three friends (Squibb, Perlman, and Place) regularly for card games at their retirement community complex. She mostly keeps to herself, always somewhat in an attitude of mourning. Quite unexpectedly she befriends her much younger pool cleaner, Lloyd, the droll Martin Starr who I've enjoyed since Freaks and Geeks. The title refers to a song that Lloyd shares with Carol. Within days another man, Bill, played by perpetual cowboy Sam Elliott, who is close to Carol's age begins flirting with her. Suddenly Carol has two men vying for her attention, paying her compliments, and encouraging her to really live life. Her friends and her daughter Katherine, played by Malin Akerman rather than her real daughter Gwyneth Paltrow, are a little puzzled by the changes in Carol but ultimately very supportive. There are heart-touching moments of sadness whether you are a retiree or you have a parent who is reaching retirement age and you realize that life doesn't need to end with isolation in what could be thirty more years of living. There are also uproarious laughs with so many comedians in this cast. This indie film was amazingly shot in 18 days and carries an energy and realistic spirit in its simple story that is especially rare.

Blythe Danner gives a real nice performance as the widow in search of some human touch but it is Martin Starr that really shines in this very enjoyable movie. His Lloyd the pool boy is a truly nuanced and heart-felt turn for the comedic actor (as we witnessed in Freaks & Geeks, Party Down and all the Aptow movies). I want to be Sam Elliott. (8--1-15)

Really good little movie, one of those "character awakening" movies with a protagonist 20 or so years older than normally portrayed. Blythe Danner is very good and creates a memorable character. Martin Starr is becoming a really solid character actor, and Sam Elliott is such a strong presence in this. Well written and subtlety performed.
well crafted and cast ensemble cast com-dram and gr8 chem between Elliot & Danner its a joy to watch.

Blythe Danner is sublime (and Oscar-worthy) as a widower who finds love and friendship after her beloved dog is put to sleep. The movie stays away from the clichï¿½ about old people finding love again and tells a touching, sometimes funny, often sad story about moving on and letting go. The ending may not be everyone's cup of tea, but life is not always going to have happy endings. Grade: B+

A heartfelt, without being overly sentimental, film about growing old and finding joy in life. #I'llseeyouinmydreams benefits greatly from fantastically nuanced performances, especially from Danner and Starr whose chemistry carries much of the film's weight.

I liked this movie in spite of the fact that it might fall into the chick flick genre. Blythe Danner is still sex at 73. She can also carry a tune. Nicely done. No thinking involved. Sit back and enjoy.
same old same old after 20 years good looking woman meets hansome man and pool boy.Has a glass of wine in her hand 90% of the time. Do you think she has a drinking problem.
What a pleasant surprise. Just rented the Netflix DVD of "I'll See You in My Dreams." Great performance by Blythe Danner. Sweet little independent film; highly recommended.
I'll See You In My Dreams [Haley, 2015] So true about the death I know. So true about the death I don't know. So true about everything, really. 9/10

The movie was thoughtful, satisfying and uplifting even in the face of its ending. We press on with life. Blythe Danner demonstrated that she has been tragically overlooked and underutilized for decades, being mostly relegated to supporting riles. She could have leading roles in quality movies such as this one. And of course, this movie and her performance were overlooked for major awards.

It isn't often in the movies that we get to look into the lives of older people. After all, in Hollywood all romances end up with two young lovers living happily ever after. But what happens after the primes of our lives have come and gone? This is what makes "I'll See You in My Dreams" such a wonderful movie. If you can make it through the first 15 minutes of the movie without shedding a tear, you are a stronger person than me. We look into the everyday life of Carol, who clearly is widowed and lives alone in a big house in Southern California. We see her waking up, going to bed, and doing everyday chores alone. Yet the movie doesn't want us to feel sorry for Carol. She herself doesn't seem to be phased by how she has had to live the las20 years of her life. Yet good things are in store for Carol, as we see her kindle a few budding romances, perform karaoke in a bar, and smoke medical marijuana with her similarly single lady friends and go on a binge trip to the grocery. All of these moments are depicted with humor, and without giving anything else a way, the movie tells us that life creeps up very fast, and there is no way to be certain you have always made the best decisions for yourself. To enjoy life and to live ifor the moment is what is important. Blythe Danner as usual is wonderful, and the tone of the film is subtle but touching.
It's the little movies like this that restore my hope in good, simplistic storytelling.
Script that goes nowhere. Little to no character development. I kept waiting for the story to develop and go some place, but it never did. Depressing.
A touching film for the autumn years that never gets too heavy or uncomfortable.
Too nuanced to be truly enjoyable. Performances were great. I hated the ending, and I am never that kind of movie watcher. This story is better suited for a subscription TV drama.
Hey, it is worth it to meet the dogs in the film.
A good little independent film: Elder-Love is possible if you look like Sam Eliot and Blyther Danner.

I liked this movie in spite of the fact that it might fall into the chick flick genre. Blythe Danner is still sex at 73. She can also carry a tune. Nicely done. No thinking involved. Sit back and enjoy.
same old same old after 20 years good looking woman meets hansome man and pool boy.Has a glass of wine in her hand 90% of the time. Do you think she has a drinking problem.

Blythe Danner is wonderful in this touching story about a woman who rediscovers herself after the death of her husband and retirement from her job as a schoolteacher. Any movie with the likes of June Squibb, Rhea Perlman and Mary Kay Place featured prominently on the poster is a rarity that would make whatever film it was worth seeing.
A good little independent film: Elder-Love is possible if you look like Sam Eliot and Blyther Danner.

Really good little movie, one of those "character awakening" movies with a protagonist 20 or so years older than normally portrayed. Blythe Danner is very good and creates a memorable character. Martin Starr is becoming a really solid character actor, and Sam Elliott is such a strong presence in this. Well written and subtlety performed.
Very good movie! Nice to see a movie that doesn't need swearing, violence, nudity, etc to entertain! The characters were believable and likable. Great movie to see with friends.
Great little movie.....
Led by nuanced performances by Blythe Danner and Sam Elliot, I'll See You In My Dreams is a sweet dramedy that warms the heart and the soul. A-

Reflections on the highs and lows in rites of passage, in this bittersweet tale channeling the female experience of aging. Along with the humorous when not harrowing cross-generational bonding that can awkwardly kick in.
Hands down, my choice for best actress for 2015. What a performance.

Simple but effective, this movie showcases how love and loss can still happen when you're older. The performances and chemistry between actors are very solid, and it offers many heartfelt moments. This is an actor's dream for sure, and the players explore a lot in their roles, especially Danner, Akerman, and the pool guy.
Slow-moving yet sweet, I'll See You in My Dreams works because of Blythe Danner's marvelous, lovable performance.
Some parts of this movie are sad but it's still a nice one to watch during the holidays. It's the best movie I've seen this year. A+++++
As a comedy-drama movie, I'll See You In My Dreams delivers because it's about relationships, and it tries and succeeds at being an indie film.
Love the entire cast. Great story. Blythe Danner is wonderful. And then you have Sam Elliott. Recommened this very hightly.
Sweet movie. Not perfect, but it does not matter. I doubt Blythe Danner will be remembered at Oscartime--but she really should. Excellent.
This is made-for-TV stuff, so how did this get a 93% rating? A good cast can't do much with a mediocre screenplay. I don't recommend this.
Like the Golden Girls, movie version....
Blythe Danner is excellent, but I'll See You in My Dreams is sweetly unremarkable across the board.
This movie sucked. Can't figure out why it got such high ratings. Frustrating to watch.
Blythe Danner acted as if she was drunk throughout the movie....the ending was bizarre...so what happened to Sam Elliott and all his money and boat all that stuff?

This is a very under rated movie and especially poignant for those of us in that age bracket...too old to be young and too young to be old. The performances are excellent and the script is far more accurate about older relationships than many of the attempts out there. I am surprised at the average of 3.7 but then many of those reviews may have been from younger people who just didn't quite get what the movie was striving for...a positive outlook. I liked it a lot. (I would love to have a many say "I think I'm liking you a little" at the end of a very obviously "connected" evening instead of the comments we women often get like "I'd sure like to make love to you" ...no comment and just grabbing you and kissing you. This author "got it"...
All these beautiful sexxy senior cast! No way do I enjoy a moustache` however, Sam Elliott is mad crazy sexy! Then there's Rhea Perlman
Danner is quite a good actress but I've seen this story hundred of times.
This is a beautiful and heartbreaking story. The cast was perfect and highly entertaining.
well crafted and cast ensemble cast com-dram and gr8 chem between Elliot & Danner its a joy to watch.
Well written, directed, and beautifully acted by seasoned pros.
A touching, funny and thoughtful film that trades in honesty rather than artifice.
A 'good' film with fine acting. HOWEVER, if you are a single woman over the age of 50 steer clear of this!!!
beautiful and somewhat inspiring movie. reminds about the fragility and shortness of the life, and that its important to open yourself up for new possibilities and new people.

The movie stays away from the clichï¿½ about old people finding love again and tells a touching, sometimes funny, often sad story about moving on and letting go. The ending may not be everyone's cup of tea, but life is not always going to have happy endings. Grade: B+
An amazing movie that I could relate to on MANY levels...love Blythe Danner...Sam Elliot I could watch all day just sitting and talking..LOL...A story about life...and remembering to live it!!!
Maybe I missed something. I thought it was flat, lukewarm performances and almost ridiculous depressing story with little depth. Disappointment.

If I am directing this movie and witness the chemistry between Danner and Sam Elliott I set up a lunch with the writers and do a re-write. Killing off Elliot so early in the story took this film from great to mediocre very quickly. This could have been a classic.

The critics are on crack to give this a 94% rating. There's absolutely no climax, no arch, no ending. Sure the characters were good, it was well scripted and the cast did a fine job, but the main character's story went absolutely nowhere. If you want the feeling that you were robbed of 90 minutes of your life, then go see it.

Can you give a movie no stars. I would. It was just plain depressing. Bummer since I was really looking forward to seeing this movie based upon the Movie Info and the audience and critic reviews. And, what a waste of Sam Shepherd. I can't imagine how this movie got 70% in audience appreciation. I'm new to the site so I don't know how to give it a rotten tomato, otherwise I would.
I rarely give top rating to anything ... but I LOVE this movie. However, it's not for average movie-goer
Great love story! Funny and true life changes for many! Enjoyed!

Always surprising to me that it is hard to find great movies like this. This is what a movie should be - funny, emotional, and a great story. The characters are all perfect casting. Definitely will recommend to everyone.

I say rent, "I'll See You In My Dreams," and watch with your parents and grandparents. Sixty is the new forty, and this movie proves it. Blythe Danner and Sam Elliott share great chemistry. This movie barely broke Seven Million Dollars at the Box Office, it should have done better.
A simple heartfelt movie that portrays just a small part of aging and not in an overly-dramatic way, while being supported by a wonderful cast with great chemistry between them.
An earnest (and not schmaltzy) tale about the joys and pains of growing old, anchored by a lucid performance by Blythe Danner.
A smart & sensible drama which works mainly because of the interesting characters!

Touching movie, about getting old and living life with whatever it has to offer. It's not a love story, it's not dramatic, it's not pulsating with vigour, but the movie is airy and lovely and sad and full of joy.
Stupid boring movie! Sam Elliott, the man still has it! The movie had no real point. I kept waiting for something to happen, and when it did it was not good!
Good drama with a different story than usual.
Boring. Fake. Conceited. You'll get nauseous watching country-club-grandma playing bridge with her friends. This is definitely in a land far, far away.

Just a nice story of what it could be like to be a retired, well to do woman, who has friends, but still feels lonely after having lost her husband. Two different types of men enter her life, one she likes, then loses again.

The one thing I'll See Youn in My Dreams has over other films about dating in seniority (i.e. Enough Said) is that it feel old-timey in a way that's heart-felt. The movie carries a real human emotion to it, that is heightened by a great sense of humor, and a really likable tone. The storyline plays it safe, but this is fine when the cast shines this affably. Blythe Danner enchants, Sam Elliot is perfectly lovable, and Martin Star finally shows he can play a character that isn't a douchey nerd. Bring your grandma to this one, and be shocked at how you'll like it just as much as her.
A small heart warming drama that shows there is lots of life to live in your older age. 10X better than the British Marigold series.

Following her as she learns to let go of certain aspects of here life and welcome in new people is just an amazing viewing experience. Love the actors, the directing, the writing... BUT I really hate sad stories. I would have loved it otherwise.

Een volwassen coming-of-age verhaal waarin Blythe Danner vrolijk verrast als een vrouw die te maken krijgt met de dood aan alle kanten, maar nog probeert het beste uit het leven te kunnen halen. Een vermakelijke film met een scherp tandje die je overduidelijk zou moeten zien met je grootouders !
I thought it was cliche, predictable, and had the dialogue of a Harlequin romance. Meh.
Surprising ending, but a very well written and performed film. Great work by Blythe Danner.

Blythe Danner gives a real nice performance as the widow in search of some human touch but it is Martin Starr that really shines in this very enjoyable movie. His Lloyd the pool boy is a truly nuanced and heart-felt turn for the comedic actor (as we witnessed in Freaks & Geeks, Party Down and all the Aptow movies). I want to be Sam Elliott. (8--1-15)

Danner is great, as is the supporting cast, but the story is wispy and thin and underdeveloped, taking a dramatic turn just as it finally seems to be ramping up. The lovely, wistful title song hints at what the filmmakers were going for.

The cast is great. Blythe Danner is better looking than her daughter and this is a very well constructed, well written film....but this just might be the most depressing movie this side of Nicholas Sparks. The move is a rollercoaster and like a rollercoaster it is fun until it makes you feel like throwing up. If you tend toward depression, go see Minions rather than this film.
Tears at your soul. Had me tearing up not 5 minutes into it.

Okay for a blatant chick-flick. Many hokey scenes. But I was entertained but all both the main characters are designed so that we really know them no better at the end than the beginning. Pool boy ends up being to only likable character because he may have a future.

This very good movie is a major "chick-flick" (although the demographic is retirement community age people) with lots of star power in the cast. Although it doesn't seem to be showing many places, yet, I'll still hold off on any additional discussion because I might inadvertently reveal information that would otherwise be known as "a spoiler" ..........

Most of it's a good bit deeper than the fluffy preview. Yes, it involves older people, with one primary exception; but that doesn't mean some of them don't have anything to say to most of us who'll be going where they are now, or are already there ourselves. For instance, one thing we could learn learn would be how how to heed Franklin's warning, "Some (many?) people die at 25 but aren't buried until 75". Franklin employed his extended longevity better than any other example I can think of.The use of a 1959 Miles Davis track for the name of Sam Elliott's boat was cool.--The ending was perfect.--

A refreshingly grounded romantic comedy-drama, I'll See You in My Dreams is a funny, mature and bittersweet examination of finding meaning and happiness in the sunset years of life, buoyed greatly by Blythe Danner's lead performance and her natural chemistry with Sam Elliott.

thoroughly enjoyable hidden gem film...needs to have a better distribution so it's target audience would appreciate and get to see it. Happy to see they still make movies about real people with real situations :)
Blythe Danner breathes life into her character and really touched me with her earnest portrayal of ageing.

Loved the cast and concept of vibrant seniors embracing their lives making the most with the time they have left----but felt the script was lacking something --and nothing in the picture tied it to its title...didn't even include the famous title song "I'll See You In My Dreams" -. evidently was a short nap & wasn't enough time to have a dream--others with me enjoyed the films sentiment. RA Reviews
Horrible! Avoid at all cost!

This is a true original. The script is flawless. For me, Martin Starr was a real find. Danner, Place, Perlman - every one of them is terrific. There is a tension throughout, the kind of tension that makes your eyes stayed gluerd to the screen.

worst movie I ever viewed this year. Sad, and Depressing. definite snore fest. would give a negative star rating. just a waste of money. Sam Elliot still cant act even as he ages and I mean these actors are old. Dull and drab.

The life of retired people is shown as empty, yet I know that not to be true.If Carol had been a teacher, a singer and a mother, then why such emptiness?Why wasn't she not involved with kids or music or even her daughter. She seemed to have died when her husband died. That is not typical.Also why so much drinking in this movie? Every other scene they were pouring a glass of wine. I know a lot of retired and semi retired people who are vitally involved with the world around them . She had made a life with her dog. Pathetic.

Almost makes sense, except for the part where she has been a widow- and never dated- for 20 years. Her relationship with the daughter, also, would seem a bit off as she must have been about 10. You might think the two of them would have formed a strong bond during her growing-up years. The girlfriends are kind of played for laughs, but it's a gentle humor all around. Oh, and Sam Elliott? I'll see him in my dreams anytime!
It was just too simple a story.... silly actually. Cafa
This is a beautiful film, lovingly crafted and acted, touching and honest from beginning to end.

Older, or "mature" Americans are one of the most under-served demographics in terms of films meant to appeal to them. Americans over 50 make up nearly 1/3 of the U.S. population. Yet, it's clear to even the most casual observer that the number of movies featuring mature themes is well under 1/3 of the movies that appear in theaters. Still, many of Hollywood's most popular actors, including Johnny Depp, Denzel Washington, Brad Pitt, Meryl Streep, Adam Baldwin and Liam Neeson, are over 50. All this makes it an unusual sight (and for those over 50, a welcome sight) when a movie with specific appeal to the AARP crowd shows up at the local multiplex. Sure, more mature Americans enjoy a variety of movies, just like all other moviegoers, but like moviegoers in all demographics, they also want to see movies to which they can relate on a very personal level. They want to be able to go to a theater and, at least some of the time, see movies that "get" them, that understand who they are, what their lives are like and what they care about. Unfortunately, quality films that fit that definition are few and far between. In the past decade, some of the better movies featuring more mature actors in the main roles and/or dealing with themes of particular interest to those over 50 include (in chronological order): "The Bucket List", "Letters to Juliet", "Enough Said", "Last Vegas", "Nebraska", "Philomena" and "Grudge Match", plus the "Expendables", "RED" and "Best Exotic Marigold Hotel" films. There are some excellent movies on that list, but there really weren't many more like them produced in recent years. Then there's "I'll See You in My Dreams" (PG-13, 1:32). So, how does that last one stack up to the others I just named?Blythe Danner (Gwyneth Paltrow's mother, who has an impressive body of work of her own, including the "Meet the Parents" films and numerous TV appearances) stars as Carol Peterson, a widow who lives alone in her comfortable Los Angeles-area house with her dog. Carol seems happy enough. She has peace and quiet, she controls her own schedule and she has friends. She makes frequent trips to a nearby retirement home to play cards with the free-spirited Sally (Rhea Perlman), the nosy Rona (Mary Kay Place) and the usually very proper Georgina (June Squibb). Carol also sometimes plays golf with Sally, and Rona occasionally stops by the house.Still, it feels like there's something missing in Carol's life and we see in her eyes and her actions that she's starting to realize it too. Carol strikes up a conversation with Lloyd (Martin Starr), the much-younger pool maintenance man and they become friends. Then she meets Bill (Sam Elliott). He's handsome, charming, self-assured and about her age. After running into Carol a couple times around town, he takes her to lunch. Soon they're going out on his boat and even Carol has to admit that she really likes him. Meanwhile, Carol's daughter, Katherine (Malin ï¿½kerman), is flying in for a visit. It's obvious that Carol and Katherine love each other, but it seems that they don't have a lot of contact and their relationship feels just a little strained. Through all these interactions, Carol seems to be gradually coming out of her shell and living her life again. Her friends and her daughter do what they can to keep Carol moving in that direction, in spite of some setbacks. And... that's about all there is to tell about "I'll See You in My Dreams" (while avoiding spoilers). This is a small and relatively short movie without much of a plot. It's a pleasant enough diversion and it has a few funny moments and a few touching moments, but it doesn't seem to have very much to say. We gain a greater understanding of what it's like to be getting older and living in a house by yourself, but the movie's messages are almost too subtle to be detected, and even the story's dramatic moments are too muted. The same can be said of a couple of the actors, but not the leads. Danner is a wonderful actress and Elliott oozes his trademark charisma. It's great to see them both back on the big screen. Perlman, Place and Squibb all have personality to spare, but can only do so much with this lackluster script. Ironically, it's Starr and Ackerman, the youngest members of the main cast, who lack the energy to make their characters compelling. Even the film's title doesn't say much. It only relates to the plot in a rather inconsequential way. I'm afraid I can't recommend this movie and it's a shame. Mature Americans who go to the theater hoping to see movies made with them in mind deserve better. "C"
The actors are very good, but the storyline sucks. I dont' want to pay to experience someone else's pitiful life - why couldn't it have a happy ending and they sail off into the sunset with her dog!

A heartfelt, without being overly sentimental, film about growing old and finding joy in life. #I'llseeyouinmydreams benefits greatly from fantastically nuanced performances, especially from Danner and Starr whose chemistry carries much of the film's weight.
It was the first movie I fell asleep at....boring!

The Old Geezers Who Go To The Matinee Alone were out in force for this one. It's about love, growing old, loss, and death; all of which are sort of central to us. Blythe Danner and Sam Elliot are outstanding, but really everyone is excellent. Martin Starr is particularly good here. A feel good if a bit sad along the way sort of movie.
Google ad said that this is a comedy. THIS IS NOT A COMEDY!! It's one small step outside of suicide: depressing.

Despite being slow, Blythe Danner's performance and its subtle sense of humor are enough to make it captivating, and it effectively carries out its message and commentary on the struggle of growing old. Good movie.
looked like it was going to be a comedy and it turned out depressing
What a flat, depressing movie! Yes, Blythe Danner was good in the main role, but I saw no true character growth, and a woman who drinks herself through every day. A waste of my time, sadly!
A fine performance by Blythe Danner turns a possibly trite screenplay into something poignant and joyful.
A really rewarding, interesting and unpredictable film Blythe Danner is terrific. Sad, funny and very charming.

Blythe Danner, Martin Starr, and Rhea Pearlman are all stellar in this and the film has some interesting things to say about how the times can influence the behavior of generations, but ultimately, I felt that there were some holes in this one... The central romance was more odd and creepy than cute and a lot of plot lines are left open and dangling in a way that required more explanation that was never even hinted at, no less offered.
Very limited script, no humor or wit. no transformation for any characters.Blythe Danner is so much better than this!!

Beautifully well shot and edited! Blythe Danner delivers a fine performance, but I could hardly call this film a romantic comedy. There are some funny moments and some great romantic chemistry between Blythe Danner and Sam Ellitot, but story is pretty depressing and sad. The writing is pretty weak. I do however enjoy Martin Starr's performance but they could've given him more. Overall It's not as good as everyone says it is. It's only an adequate film. My grade=80%(B-).
Glacial pace, too bad they wasted Sam Elliott's talent on this snoozer.
A very good movie...

Terribly shallow, boring lives. Aging isn't easy but these ladies make it look as empty as their preoccupation with drinking, relapse, and sexual innuendo that has little to do with the intimacy I imagine they would prefer. Don't waste your money on this "dog".

I'll See You In My Dreams is about a older women Carol Peterson played by Blythe Danner. She just trying to go through life after the death of he husband a few years before. She plays cards with a group of older lady June Squibb, Gorgina,Rhea Perlman ,Sally and Mary Kay Pace, Rona friends each week. Sally asks Carol to go to a speed dating session with her. Carol ends up meeting Bill played by Sam Elliot and they hit it off pretty quickly. She also befriends a pool guy Loyd played by Martin Starr and they go to karaoke together. Malin Ackerman plays Carol's daughter and she come for a visit and helps Carol out with advise on these strange changes in her every day life. Blythe Danner gives the performance of her career and she is fantastic in this role. She gives the best performance of the year by a lead actress so far this year. The comedy aspect and relationships in the film are so realistic and genuine. I loved I'll See You In My Dreams I give it a big See-It. from Dan Skip Allen
Geriatric chick flick, scripted by someone who imagines that SoCal is a real place. Danner and Elliott served up eye candy for the Medicare set, otherwise a boring experience.
Such a joy for those of us "north of 60 years old."

We saw "I'll See You in my Dreams" Saturday at Mark Cuban's Landmark Theater in West LA. Good plot and good acting. Some very sad scenes, though. I liked the movie and I think you will too. 3.5 stars. On another note the parking at this theater (located inside the Westside Pavilion) is awful. It took nearly 20 minutes to get out of the parking lot.

I had high hopes for "See You In My Dreams" based on the cast, thoughtful content, and trailer, but this movie fails to deliver. Sam Elliott and Mary Kay Place are two of my favorite actors, bringing a sensitive undercurrent to the empty shell of a script - such a waste that they had nothing to work with in the way of dialogue and character development. Rhea Pearlman brought the only zing and pep in a plodding, clichï¿½ of a story about a woman who shut her life down for the past 20 years following the death of her husband. Blythe Danner, who has always been overrated, put her all into playing Carol Peterson, a tight-lipped woman who is internalized and numb. In combination with a script that fails to ever go anywhere near deep, her character is a shell we can't feel and can barely care about. She lost me when in her fairly empty life she can't seem to make the effort to welcome her daughter or inquire about her life. A scene that brings a couple of welcome laughs, when the girlfriends get stoned together, is ruined by the implausible threat of a bust by a police officer as they walk their shopping cart back to the retirement home. This is a dreary waste of time.
Really a dud. Not worth seeing.

Interesting new film pickins' have been real slim of late. Was all setto see "Aloha" when allergies/pollen simply laid me out. With this delay Iinadvertentlystarting hearing/seeing (without trying)reviews about the strong cast/director picture yet the film was "ugly"So was looking forward to the indy-ish film "I'll See You In My Dreams" starringthe always under the radar "Blythe Danner" who often plays the role of a calm,quiet/gentle Mom/Mother. But she has killer blue eyes that dance on the bigscreen. I'm not sure she's ever gotten singular, top billing in a prominentfilm yet deserves it. As she doesn't grace the big screen too often and shedeserves our undivided attention.This films "disappoints" but "is not" disappointing. Really tugs at someemotional themes while intersecting with some awesome "golden girls" likecomedy.Seriously, comedic jousting and talking between best friends (senior and single)Danner, June Squibb (of Nebraska fame), Rhea Perlman (Cheers) and Mary Kay Place(lots) is a home run. I, and I'm sure many others were desperate for morescreen time for this Quad Squad?they were magical. This film wanted to exploredeeper themes for Danner which were important, just not nearly as warm and fuzzy.The first 10 minutes a wonderfully poignant and accurate portrayal of her main friendshipwith her dog Hazel and the dogs subsequent euthanized death (been their 4 timesand captured very well) set forth several new paths.Closer relationship with her friends; sort of an odd lightly flirtatiousrelationship with "the dorky pool boy"; closer bonding with her core 4friends; exploring her 1st serious relationship since her husbands passing20 years prior (with the hunky Sam Elliot) takes quite a twist; and aconnecting with her only relative, daughter all play major themes inthis film.I like the shortness of the film (90 minutes) but in some parts it drags.Still this was a very fine film with emotional highs and lows and no doubt,that light banter between the friends stole the film and easily was worththe price of admission.

I absolutely loved I'll See You in My Dreams, which opened the Cleveland International Film Fest in 2015!! It succeeds because of the funny, sweet and stellar ensemble cast. Carol Petersen (Blythe Danner) is a widow with a routine. She lives independently, but visits her three friends (Squibb, Perlman, and Place) regularly for card games at their retirement community complex. She mostly keeps to herself, always somewhat in an attitude of mourning. Quite unexpectedly she befriends her much younger pool cleaner, Lloyd, the droll Martin Starr who I've enjoyed since Freaks and Geeks. The title refers to a song that Lloyd shares with Carol. Within days another man, Bill, played by perpetual cowboy Sam Elliott, who is close to Carol's age begins flirting with her. Suddenly Carol has two men vying for her attention, paying her compliments, and encouraging her to really live life. Her friends and her daughter Katherine, played by Malin Akerman rather than her real daughter Gwyneth Paltrow, are a little puzzled by the changes in Carol but ultimately very supportive. There are heart-touching moments of sadness whether you are a retiree or you have a parent who is reaching retirement age and you realize that life doesn't need to end with isolation in what could be thirty more years of living. There are also uproarious laughs with so many comedians in this cast. This indie film was amazingly shot in 18 days and carries an energy and realistic spirit in its simple story that is especially rare.

Very highly recommended but I feel the Director went a bit too far out of his way to say he will not adhere to Hollywood formula. Never-the-less, there are many small pleasures captured in various wonderful scenes. But nothing wrong with making the same film a bit more upbeat. That's why folks go to the movies. So nice to see a film with no shaky camera, no found footage and no buildings collapsing. The camera lingers on the actors and brings them to life. Blythe is a marvel. Don't miss it.

The Perfect coming of age movie of this Generation. The penultimate show about, and for all narcissi. Do we really need more movies fixated on self fixated people pondering there self fixated lives - no wonder so many are so worried about there significance and happiness - I mean what else could be as important - to them? I wasn't sure if I should laugh or cry - I went home and washed.

This movie was far from "vibrant." It was not particularly funny, mildly amusing at best, and just downbeat a lot of the time, portraying the foibles of affluent white retirees in a posh retirement community. It is not particularly profound. The central character, Carol, had some potential but I left the theater wishing I had waited for it to go to the dollar theater.

+I don't know if 2 movies of the same genre are the start of a trend but I hope so. During the second week of May I went to see "Five Flights Up", a movie about an elderly couple together for forty years with neither dying of Alzheimer's or any other 'old people' diseases nor were they battling with being an inter-racial couple. They were a pair who made and enjoyed a life together the only trauma being of the old man and their old dog having to climb 5 flights of stairs. The leads were played by Diane Keaton and Morgan Freeman each looking and feeling comfortable in their long term relationship and the audience believed in them.This week I saw "I'll See You In MY Dreams" with Blythe Danner sparkling in her role as an independent woman, a retired school teacher, who, when younger, had dabbled as a band singer, now a widow for 20 years, has a daughter who lives on the other coast and they maintain a mother/daughter relationship and friendship. She lives in her own home having enough money to maintain it along with hiring a pool boy. Her major conflict at this point in life is that she may have to put down her beloved Hazel, a dog, of 12 years. Just watching the light go out of Danner's blue eyes as the procedure is done is the dramatic moment of the movie though other things do happen.Danner plays cards with her girlfriends June Squibb, Rhea Perlman and Mary Kay Place, all who are trying to get her to move into the retirement community where they live. These are women who have adapted to being seniors who can get goofy on medical marijuana, go on a speed dating romp, play golf, talk a little 'naughty', drink some, well a lot, of wine.When Mary Kay sees Danner's pool boy leaving her house early one morning she is not above thinking what most women would think and when a handsome, virile looking, possibly Mr. Right in the form of Sam Elliot shows up in a meet cute scene you think you know where the movie is heading just as you might justifiably think you know what will happen between Danner and the pool boy Martin Starr when they go to a karaoke bar on what might be or not be a date.Directed by Brett Haley, who also wrote it along with Marc Basch, this is not a Golden Girls television situation comedy or a cougar and young man story or woman desperate for another man to make their life whole. This is a film, like "5 Flights Up", that looks at a group of people who have lived most of their life, are near the end, and still find aspects to explore. Actually along with "Love Is Strange" starring John Lithgow and Alfred Molina, these pictures show professional actors who have always supported others with first class work now doing the same with and for others giving themselves a chance to be the stars they are.PS No one ever made scarves look as good as Blythe Danner's face and eyes do!
Best movie so far in 2015. Oscar worthy performance by Blythe Danner. Great writing, directing and music. I LOVED IT!!!!!!!!!
It examines a topic that could be sad and makes it interesting!
This movie is so great! We saw it at the Louisiana International Film Festival. It will release soon...go see it, you'll see a perspective of life you don't see often!

Such a delightful film in every way. Blythe Danner is radiant and lovable as Carol who is pretty much in every scene of this movie and you know why because it's a performance that you can't take your eyes off of. Right off the gate, the movie just lets out a scene that makes you want to ball your eyes out but picks back up with delightful scenes with Carol and her new pool boy played spectacularly by Martin Starr. I could watch these two talk all day their chemistry was that wonderful. It kind of threw me off because the trailers make you think this movie's focus would be more on Blythe Danner and Sam Elliot's relationship but it really is more centered around Danner and Starr at first. But when Sam Elliot comes along, you will smile and it will make your heart warm. The movie is actually more dramatic than comedic leaving the comedy to the pros Rhea Perlman, June Squibb, and Mary Kay Place. Malin Akerman and Reid Scott have great small parts that I wish were longer but were worth their time. The movie kind of plays out like a play with Blythe focused on a friendship in the first act and a relationship in the second but it flows so well and makes you want to stay with these characters longer than the movie. I thought the movie could have been a little more funnier with the light tone it was providing and I wanted more scenes with the girls and with Malin Akerman in mother/daughter bonding scenes but overall in this summer of explosions and sequels, this is definitely the best alternative if that's not your thing. Even if those are your thing, this is such a warm and loving movie that will make you want to hug the person sitting next to you in the theater. Also I'm not 100% sure if the song sung at the very end and then again in the credits is original or just a cover but if it is original, I would love to see it get a nomination for Original Song. Really beautifully written and summed up the movie. I suspect that the Globes will take this movie as a Comedy so I hope Danner is remembered by the end of the year. After seeing this, you'll scratch your head why Danner isn't a bigger star headlining more movies like this

I've always been in love with Sam Elloitt....I think that he is just one of the sexiest males in hollwood. This movie needs to come to a theatre in my neck of the woods cause i'm dying to see it and him

So glad there are theaters that will show "real" films. The story and acting were superb. There was even one scene that brought a tear to my eye. No explosions, and only a brief discreet sex scene, but still a great movie. Anyone would enjoy, but those over the age of 50 would fully understand.
A good romantic comedy/drama which simply presents life and how you should enjoy every moment of it.
This movie looks perfect! I wish it was playing somewhere that I could find it. Even though it is listed as opening May 15th in selected theaters, I can't find any mention of it anywhere!
If you recently lost a pet, skip this movie for now.

Went to this on a whim because of the great tomatometer percent (91%), and it was sweet. An older woman who loses her dog finds comfort in befriending the pool boy. She has girlfriends but hasn't been with a guy in 20 years, (which I didn't believe), then she meets Sam Elliott. Blythe carries the film effortlessly, but it didn't have enough impact or emotional punch for me to say I would recommend it. It's light and straightforward, well-acted--not uplifting or particularly moving. I would like to see how a French director would film a French version of similar subject matter.

I guess I'm out of the loop given the high scores from critics and movie goers for this. It's a maudlin, saccharine, dramady for senior citizens. The plot isn't the point; it's more a mediatation on the passage of time, the meaning of life and how life's not fair. New stuff? Nah. Blythe Danner radiates elder class and beauty and Sam Elliott is always enjoyable. Carol (Danner) plays bridge at the retirement home she refuses to retire to and her gal pals are gossipy bridge partners. Along comes her pool man (no, not that pool man) who is a kindred lost soul. They bond over karaoke and becomes each other's emotional support. It's a triffle of a film and good to know that older female actors can continue to demonstrate their skills.

An effecting drama with ample light touches to offset the surprisingly profound messages of life and loss. Excellent performances and heart-tugging moments abound, grabbing the audience and making an emotional impact in unexpected ways. With that said, however, the film could use some tidying up in the writing and editing departments, but those shortfalls don't significantly detract from what is an otherwise-worthwhile cinematic experience.
a wonderful look into the world of seniors with an outstanding acting jobby Blythe Danner.
Great acting and authentic dialogue make this a must see. Blythe Danner is amazing and an inspiration at 72. Each subject is addressed in a deep and authentic manner.
Marvelous, apt, real
She was radiant and the language and acting seemed natural.Interesting, engaging and thoughtful.
Nonesense, all action non substance

Although these kind of older people movies are usually hard for me to put myself into, I was both pleased and engaged by I'll see you in my dreams, it's a warm hearted dramedy that's bolstered by Blythe Danner's brilliant lead performance

See you in my dreams is an outstanding film with fantastic performances from it's amazing cast. Blythe Danner is oscarworthy with her funny, fresh, subtle performance as the lead. But all of the cast take their turn as Martin Starr, Rhea Perlman, Sam Eliot, Mary Kay Place, June Squib and Malin Ackerman all add to the movie in their own way. The film will make you laugh and cry, and leave you feeling good. The movie is a must see.

This was shown the final evening of the Sarasota (FL) Film Festival, and it was wonderful. The audience loved it. We were screaming with laughter during some of the scenes, and the film also choked us up with tears. A fabulous,clever, heartfelt adult movie.
This is a must see for date night!
Looks good I want to see it

1st of all....Sam Elliott is so hot. Still got that pitter patter I got when I saw him in Lifeguard in 1975 or so. Amazing how a 30 year old man wrote this very moving story about people struggling throughwhat at 1st glance are "older people problems" but truly they are problems we often are faced with in younger years as well. Funny, sad & worth seeing for sure. All of the womeni were fantastic too but you can't blame me for the shout out to Sam :-)
I like just about every movie Sam Elliott has been in. Sounds like a nice movie to watch with my wife.
Smart, funny, and real. I absolutely loved this movie.
OMG, it's time someone made a eraOMG, it's time they made a film about cool people as they age..age is a number. period.
can't wait to see it
I have seen this one over & over again - It is just watchable, like a favorite CD that you play when it is the right time. The Jolson Story is another one like it.
Great little film. Danny Kaye and Doris Day are wonderful. Yes sappy and sentimental but so good. Mary Wickes is a hoot.
Great little film. Danny Kaye and Doris Day are wonderful. Yes sappy and sentimental but so good. Mary Wickes is a hoot.
Day and Thomas work well together in this fun rollercoaster musical ride.
no thanks not my thing
Based on composer Gus Kahn's life, Danny Thomas gives one of his better performances. Doris Day is fine as his wife. Good musical numbers but a little over sentimental.
